\begin{align} \int_a^b f(x)\cdot dx &= \int_a^b f\left(a + b - x \right)\cdot dx \\ \therefore \int_0^a f(x)\cdot dx &= \int_0^a f\left( a-x\right)\cdot dx \\ \int_0^{2a}f(x)\cdot dx &= \underbrace{\int_0^a f(x)\cdot dx + \int_0^a f(2a - x)\cdot dx}_{0\rightarrow a\text{ in both integrals}} \end{align}
%text
The last property gives rise to the following
% \int_0^{2a} f(x)\cdot dx = \begin{cases} 2\int_0^a f(x)\cdot dx \text{ if } f(2a - x) = f(x) \\ 0\text{ if } f(2a - x) = -f(x) \end{cases} %text
\textbf{Odd and even functions}
If \[ f(x) = f(-x) \], then $f(x)$ is an even function. And therefore, \[ \qquad \int_{-a}^a f(x) \cdot dx = 2\int_0^a f(x)\cdot dx \]
But if \[ f(-x) = - f(x) \], then $f(x)$ is an odd function. In that case \[ \qquad \int_{-a}^a f(x)\cdot dx = 0 \] %
